Model evaluation in experimental plots

Miquel De Cáceres (CREAF), Víctor Granda (CREAF), Rafael Poyatos (CREAF), Nicolas Martin-StPaul (INRAE)

2024-03-08

Source: vignettes/evaluation/StandLevelEvaluation.Rmd
StandLevelEvaluation.Rmd

Introduction

This document presents medfate (ver. 4.0.0) model evaluation results at stand-level, using data from a set of 12 experimental forest plots. The main source of observed data is SAPFLUXNET database (Poyatos et al. 2021).

List of sites

Plot Country Stand
Puéchabon France Dense evergreen forest dominated by Q. ilex
Hesse France Naturally regenerated, managed beech forest
Yatir Israel Pinus halepensis managed plantation
Rinconada Spain Young, homogeneous, Quercus pyrenaica regrowth forest
Vallcebre (Cal Barrol) Spain Semi-deciduous sub-Mediterranean oak forest
Vallcebre (Cal Sort) Spain Pinus sylvestris forest in a terraced area
Fontainebleau-Barbeau France Mixed deciduous forest
Prades (Tillar valley) Spain Mixed forest with P. sylvestris (overstory) Q. ilex (midstory)
Font-Blanche France Mixed forest with P. halepensis and Q. ilex
Can Balasc Spain Mixed forest dominated by Q. ilex
Alto Tajo (Armallones) Spain Sparse mixed forest dominated by three species
Ronda (Pilones) Spain Mixed gimnosperm forest dominated by Abies pinsapo

Simulation and evaluation procedure

Forest water balance simulations (i.e. function spwb()) have been conducted using the three transpiration modes (i.e. Granier, Sperry or Cochard). Only soil characteristics have been tuned, but calibration exercises have not been conducted. When available, however, leaf area to sapwood area ratios have been used. Thus, the evaluation is meant to be more or less representative of simulations with default species-level trait data.

For each forest plot, general information about the site, topography, soil and climate is first presented, followed by a description of model inputs. Then, evaluation results are presented for four different variables:

  1. Stand-level evapo-transpiration.
  2. Soil moisture content of the topmost layer.
  3. Species-level transpiration, scaled from sap-flow data.
  4. Predawn and midday leaf water potentials.
